triples.name: Parametric polymorphism
triples.relevance: The paper builds on parametric polymorphism to analyze how seq affects free theorems in polymorphic functional languages.

triples.name: Parametricity
triples.relevance: Parametricity is the fundamental property that enables free theorems, which is the central concern of the paper.

triples.name: Haskell (programming language)
triples.relevance: Haskell is the primary programming language analyzed in the paper, specifically its seq operator and lazy evaluation semantics.

triples.name: Lazy evaluation
triples.relevance: Lazy evaluation is fundamental to Haskell's nonstrict semantics which interacts with seq in ways that affect parametricity.

triples.name: System F
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes a Girard-Reynolds calculus (System F) with fixpoints and algebraic datatypes as the basis for their parametricity results.

triples.name: Fixed point (mathematics)
triples.relevance: Fixpoints are a key component of the calculus examined in the paper, allowing recursive definitions.

triples.name: Algebraic data type
triples.relevance: Algebraic datatypes are a core feature of the language and formal system analyzed in the paper.

triples.name: Program transformation
triples.relevance: The paper derives new criteria ensuring that program transformations based on free theorems remain valid in the presence of seq.

triples.name: Deforestation (computer science)
triples.relevance: Shortcut fusion (a form of deforestation) is specifically analyzed as a program transformation that must satisfy new criteria in the presence of seq.
